uncertainty_register.unknown: Historical bookings trends (3-5 years) to distinguish temporary vs structural decline - is 21% bookings decline sudden shock (2024 only) or endpoint of multi-year deterioration?
uncertainty_register.decision_impact: CRITICAL - Determines whether bookings weakness is RECOVERABLE (temporary 2024 event, could rebound 2025-2026) vs TERMINAL (multi-year declining trend, will continue declining or stabilize at low level). If bookings declined gradually over 3-5 years (2020: $2.0B → 2024: $1.36B = -32% cumulative, -7% CAGR), indicates STRUCTURAL DETERIORATION with low recovery probability. If bookings were stable $1.7-1.8B through 2023 then sudden -21% decline 2024, suggests INFLECTION POINT from specific 2024 events (VMware pricing shock timing, hyperscaler competitive escalation, macro environment), may have some recovery potential if triggers reverse. Affects: (1) Revenue forecasting confidence (structural decline projects to $1.0-1.2B revenue 2027-2028, temporary shock projects to $1.2-1.3B recovery), (2) M&A valuation (structural terminal decline = harvest/liquidation value only, temporary shock = potential turnaround value), (3) Management credibility (gradual decline suggests management KNEW business deteriorating for years but masked with financial engineering, sudden decline suggests management SURPRISED by 2024 deterioration).
uncertainty_register.what_would_reduce_uncertainty: MANAGEMENT ACCESS REQUIRED. Request: Annual bookings values 2020-2024 (five years to show trend), quarterly bookings 2023-2024 (shows inflection timing), segment-level bookings trends (which segments deteriorating vs stable). This is STANDARD SaaS/subscription business metric that management must track for forecasting and investor reporting. If Rackspace is PE-owned (Apollo), PE sponsor definitely monitors bookings trends closely. WITHOUT DATA: can infer from revenue trends (revenue declining 7% YoY suggests bookings likely declining for 2-3 years prior given 1-3 year lag from bookings to revenue), but cannot determine magnitude of historical bookings decline vs current 21%. Use PESSIMISTIC scenario (bookings declining 10-15% annually 2021-2024, structural) for base case, MODERATE scenario (bookings stable 2021-2023 then -21% in 2024, inflection) for sensitivity.

uncertainty_register.unknown: Magnitude of silent price erosion mechanisms - how much margin compression attributable to scope expansion, cost absorption, compliance burden vs other factors (inefficiency, competitive cost disadvantage)?
uncertainty_register.decision_impact: MATERIAL - Determines whether margin compression (3.1% EBITDA, Stage 2.2) is primarily PRICING FAILURE (delivering more value for same price = recoverable by repricing or reducing scope) vs COST STRUCTURE FAILURE (inherently uncompetitive cost base = requires restructuring or exit). If 60-80% of margin compression is silent price erosion (scope creep, cost absorption), suggests pricing discipline could restore 3-5 percentage points of margin (3.1% EBITDA → 6-8% EBITDA achievable through scope management, cost pass-through, compliance repricing). If only 20-30% is pricing erosion and 70-80% is cost structure disadvantage (Stage 3.2: 25.9% SG&A vs 10-15% competitors, 50-70% labor cost gap), margin restoration requires FUNDAMENTAL RESTRUCTURING (layoffs, offshoring, infrastructure consolidation) not pricing actions. Affects strategic options: pricing-driven compression = tactical fixes possible (scope governance, renewal discipline, cost pass-through enforcement), cost-structure-driven compression = strategic transformation required (not available given competitive dynamics) or acceptance of low margins.
uncertainty_register.what_would_reduce_uncertainty: PARTIALLY REDUCIBLE through management data analysis. Request: (1) Customer-level profitability analysis showing gross margin by customer segment and variance over time (identifies where margins compressed most = likely scope creep or cost absorption), (2) Services delivered per dollar of revenue by segment and trend (quantifies scope expansion - if delivering 1.5x services in 2024 vs 1.0x in 2019 at same revenue, proves 33% silent price erosion), (3) SG&A breakdown by cost category with trends (separates service delivery costs from overhead to isolate pricing-driven vs structure-driven margin compression), (4) Compliance cost tracking (total cost of FedRAMP, SOC 2, ISO certifications, regulatory burden with 5-year trend - quantifies compliance burden escalation). Management SHOULD have this data for operational management (customer profitability, service delivery efficiency). WITHOUT DATA: can estimate directionally from evidence (Stage 3.4 identifies five major silent erosion mechanisms, combined impact estimated 20-50% cumulative over 5 years = 4-10% annual margin impact, but ranges are wide). Use MODERATE assumption (silent erosion = 40% of margin pressure, cost structure = 60%) for base case.

uncertainty_register.unknown: Customer-level pricing and discount distribution - what percentage of customers receive material discounts (15%+ off list), and is discounting concentrated (few large customers) or distributed (systematic across base)?
uncertainty_register.decision_impact: MODERATE-HIGH - Determines whether discounting is NEGOTIABLE REALITY (few large customers with leverage extract discounts = can be managed through customer segmentation, selective retention) vs SYSTEMATIC NECESSITY (majority of customers demand discounts = cannot be reversed without mass churn). If discounting is concentrated in 10-20% of customers (large enterprises with procurement leverage, customers threatened to churn), Rackspace could potentially ACCEPT CHURN on most price-sensitive customers and MAINTAIN PRICING on remaining 80-90% (shrink to profitability strategy). If discounting is distributed across 60-80% of customer base (systematic market pricing pressure, all customers benchmark and demand competitive pricing), no path to margin restoration through pricing (cannot lose 60-80% of customers, cannot maintain pricing across base). Also affects bookings recovery potential: concentrated discounting suggests TEMPORARY WEAKNESS (2024 saw disproportionate large customer churn or renewal concessions, could stabilize 2025-2026), distributed discounting suggests PERMANENT REPRICING (entire market has reset expectations downward, prices will not recover).
uncertainty_register.what_would_reduce_uncertainty: MANAGEMENT ACCESS REQUIRED. Request: (1) Distribution of customer-level discount rates (histogram showing percentage of revenue at 0-5% discount, 5-10%, 10-15%, 15-20%, 20%+ vs list pricing), (2) Renewal discount trends over time (are renewal concessions increasing or stable - 2022 average 5%, 2023 average 10%, 2024 average 15% would show acceleration), (3) New customer acquisition pricing vs existing customer pricing (are new customers obtained at discounts indicating market pricing reset, or at list pricing indicating discounting is retention-specific). This is standard sales operations data maintained in CRM systems. WITHOUT DATA: can infer from bookings gap (21% bookings decline with 12-15% customer churn suggests 9% effective price reduction across portfolio = DISTRIBUTED DISCOUNTING affecting majority of renewals, not concentrated in few customers). Use PESSIMISTIC assumption (distributed discounting affecting 60-70% of base) for base case given bookings gap magnitude.

uncertainty_register.unknown: VMware-based Private Cloud pricing pass-through actual outcomes - what percentage of customers accepted price increases vs negotiated concessions vs churned? What was average price increase achieved vs VMware cost increase faced?
uncertainty_register.decision_impact: CRITICAL - Determines actual Private Cloud segment viability given VMware cost shock. Stage 3.4 inference: Rackspace facing $100-210M VMware cost increase, Private Cloud declining 13% ($72M revenue loss). THREE SCENARIOS possible: (1) FULL PASS-THROUGH with high churn (40-60% of customers accepted price increases, 13% churned, Rackspace maintained margins but lost significant revenue), (2) PARTIAL PASS-THROUGH with moderate churn (50-70% of cost increase passed through, 13% churn, margins compressed but manageable), (3) ABSORPTION with low churn (20-40% of cost passed through, customers resisted increases, Rackspace absorbed $60-125M cost = margins collapsed to zero/negative). Each scenario has different implications: Scenario 1 = segment becomes smaller but viable (harvest declining base at acceptable margins), Scenario 2 = segment becomes low-margin declining asset (zombie economics), Scenario 3 = segment unprofitable requiring immediate restructuring or exit. Current evidence (13% revenue decline, 3.1% company-wide EBITDA) suggests Scenario 2-3 (partial absorption, margins compressed), but magnitude uncertain.
uncertainty_register.what_would_reduce_uncertainty: MANAGEMENT ACCESS CRITICAL. Request: (1) VMware-based Private Cloud customer outcomes 2024-2025: percentage accepting price increases, average increase accepted, percentage churning, (2) Private Cloud segment margin 2023 vs 2024 (shows margin compression from VMware costs), (3) Account team feedback on customer reactions to VMware pricing discussions (negotiation dynamics, customer alternatives evaluated, concessions demanded). This is BUSINESS-CRITICAL data for Private Cloud survival that executive management must know. WITHOUT DATA: Must model scenarios with wide ranges (Scenario 2-3 most likely, margins compressed 3-7 percentage points = Private Cloud at 0-4% EBITDA, unsustainable). Use SCENARIO ANALYSIS with Scenario 2 (partial pass-through, low single-digit margins, gradual decline) as base case, Scenario 3 (absorption, negative margins, requires restructuring) as stress case.

uncertainty_register.unknown: Management awareness and response to pricing deterioration - does leadership recognize bookings collapse and margin compression as existential threats requiring urgent action, or view as temporary weakness?
uncertainty_register.decision_impact: MATERIAL - Affects both DILIGENCE ASSESSMENT (is management credible and realistic vs in denial) and OUTCOME PROBABILITY (urgent response may slow deterioration, complacency accelerates decline). If management RECOGNIZES crisis (bookings -21%, margins 3.1%, pricing power zero), may take AGGRESSIVE ACTIONS (cost restructuring, portfolio exits, accelerated M&A process to find buyer before further deterioration). If management DENIES crisis (views as temporary softness, cyclical downturn, execution issues), will pursue BUSINESS-AS-USUAL (incremental cost cuts, sales execution improvement, product enhancement) that are INSUFFICIENT for structural crisis. Affects M&A process: (1) Realistic management will provide candid data and conservative projections (trustworthy counterparty, but emphasizes problems), (2) Denying management will present optimistic case and hide problems (unreliable counterparty, creates diligence risk of hidden issues). Also affects POST-ACQUISITION: realistic management can be retained and given execution plan, denying management must be replaced (adds integration complexity and cost).
uncertainty_register.what_would_reduce_uncertainty: PARTIALLY REDUCIBLE through management discussions and document review. Diligence process should include: (1) CEO/CFO interviews asking directly about bookings trends, pricing pressure, margin compression (listen for candid acknowledgment vs deflection/rationalization), (2) Board presentation review (what does management tell Board about business health - realistic assessment or optimistic spin?), (3) PE sponsor (Apollo) assessment (PE sponsors typically have realistic view, less tolerance for denial - Apollo's perspective on Rackspace health reveals whether management view is credible), (4) Strategic plan review (does plan acknowledge structural issues requiring transformation vs assumes business recovers with execution improvements?). Management tone and realism will become apparent through diligence interactions. WITHOUT ACCESS: cannot determine management awareness. Use BASE ASSUMPTION: PE-owned companies typically have realistic management (PE sponsors enforce reality), but Apollo's ownership since 2016 (8+ years) may indicate tolerance for subpar performance (hasn't driven exit or turnaround, suggests either patient capital or trapped in declining asset).
